00034 #if !defined(GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC)
00035 /**
00036  * The precision of floating point numbers used in %GeographicLib.  0 means
00037  * float; 1 (default) means double; 2 means long double.  Nearly all the
00038  * testing has been carried out with doubles and that's the recommended
00039  * configuration.  Note that with Microsoft Visual Studio, long double is the
00040  * same as double.
00041  **********************************************************************/
00042 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC 1
00043 #endif

00045 #include <cmath>

00050 /**
00051  * \brief Namespace for %GeographicLib
00052  *
00053  * All of %GeographicLib is defined within the GeographicLib namespace.  In
00054  * addtion all the header files are included via %GeographicLib/filename.  This
00055  * minimizes the likelihood of conflicts with other packages.
00056  **********************************************************************/
00057 namespace GeographicLib {
00058 
00059   /**
00060    * \brief Mathematical functions needed by %GeographicLib
00061    *
00062    * Define mathematical functions in order to localize system dependencies and
00063    * to provide generic versions of the functions.  In addition define a real
00064    * type to be used by %GeographicLib.
00065    **********************************************************************/
00066   class Math {
00067   private:
00068     void dummy() {
00069       STATIC_ASSERT((GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC) >= 0 && (GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC) <= 2,
00070                     "Bad value of precision");
00071     }
00072     Math();                     // Disable constructor
00073   public:
00074 
00075 #if GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 1
00076     /**
00077      * The real type for %GeographicLib. Nearly all the testing has been done
00078      * with \e real = double.  However, the algorithms should also work with
00079      * float and long double (where available).
00080      **********************************************************************/
00081     typedef double real;
00082 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 0
00083     typedef float real;
00084 #elif GEOGRAPHICLIB_PREC == 2
00085     typedef long double real;
00086 #else
00087     typedef double real;
00088 #endif
00089 
00090 #if defined(DOXYGEN)
00091     /**
00092      * Return sqrt(\e x<sup>2</sup> + \e y<sup>2</sup>) avoiding underflow and
00093      * overflow.
00094      **********************************************************************/
00095     static inline real hypot(real x, real y) throw() {
00096       x = std::abs(x);
00097       y = std::abs(y);
00098       real
00099         a = std::max(x, y),
00100         b = std::min(x, y) / a;
00101       return a * std::sqrt(1 + b * b);
00102     }
00103 #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
00104     static inline double hypot(double x, double y) throw()
00105     { return _hypot(x, y); }
00106     static inline float hypot(float x, float y) throw()
00107     { return _hypotf(x, y); }
00108 #else
00109     // Use overloading to define generic versions
00110     static inline double hypot(double x, double y) throw()
00111     { return ::hypot(x, y); }
00112     static inline float hypot(float x, float y) throw()
00113     { return ::hypotf(x, y); }
00114     static inline long double hypot(long double x, long double y) throw()
00115     { return ::hypotl(x, y); }
00116 #endif
00117 
00118 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || defined(_MSC_VER)
00119     /**
00120      * Return exp(\e x) - 1 accurate near \e x = 0.  This is taken from
00121      * N. J. Higham, Accuracy and Stability of Numerical Algorithms, 2nd
00122      * Edition (SIAM, 2002), Sec 1.14.1, p 19.
00123      **********************************************************************/
00124     static inline real expm1(real x) throw() {
00125       volatile real
00126         y = std::exp(x),
00127         z = y - 1;
00128       // The reasoning here is similar to that for log1p.  The expression
00129       // mathematically reduces to exp(x) - 1, and the factor z/log(y) = (y -
00130       // 1)/log(y) is a slowly varying quantity near y = 1 and is accurately
00131       // computed.
00132       return std::abs(x) > 1 ? z : z == 0 ?  x : x * z / std::log(y);
00133     }
00134 #else
00135     static inline double expm1(double x) throw() { return ::expm1(x); }
00136     static inline float expm1(float x) throw() { return ::expm1f(x); }
00137     static inline long double expm1(long double x) throw()
00138     { return ::expm1l(x); }
00139 #endif
00140 
00141 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || defined(_MSC_VER)
00142     /**
00143      * Return log(\e x + 1) accurate near \e x = 0.  This is taken See
00144      * D. Goldberg,
00145      * <a href="http://docs.sun.com/source/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html"> What
00146      * every computer scientist should know about floating-point arithmetic</a>
00147      * (1991), Theorem 4.  See also, Higham (op. cit.), Answer to Problem 1.5,
00148      * p 528.
00149      **********************************************************************/
00150     static inline real log1p(real x) throw() {
00151       volatile real
00152         y = 1 + x,
00153         z = y - 1;
00154       // Here's the explanation for this magic: y = 1 + z, exactly, and z
00155       // approx x, thus log(y)/z (which is nearly constant near z = 0) returns
00156       // a good approximation to the true log(1 + x)/x.  The multiplication x *
00157       // (log(y)/z) introduces little additional error.
00158       return z == 0 ? x : x * std::log(y) / z;
00159     }
00160 #else
00161     static inline double log1p(double x) throw() { return ::log1p(x); }
00162     static inline float log1p(float x) throw() { return ::log1pf(x); }
00163     static inline long double log1p(long double x) throw()
00164     { return ::log1pl(x); }
00165 #endif
00166 
00167 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || defined(_MSC_VER)
00168     /**
00169      * Return asinh(\e x).  This is defined in terms of log1p(\e x) in order to
00170      * maintain accuracy near \e x = 0.  In addition, the odd parity of the
00171      * function is enforced.
00172      **********************************************************************/
00173     static inline real asinh(real x) throw() {
00174       real y = std::abs(x);     // Enforce odd parity
00175       y = log1p(y * (1 + y/(hypot(real(1), y) + 1)));
00176       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00177     }
00178 #else
00179     static inline double asinh(double x) throw() { return ::asinh(x); }
00180     static inline float asinh(float x) throw() { return ::asinhf(x); }
00181     static inline long double asinh(long double x) throw()
00182     { return ::asinhl(x); }
00183 #endif
00184 
00185 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || defined(_MSC_VER)
00186     /**
00187      * Return atanh(\e x).  This is defined in terms of log1p(\e x) in order to
00188      * maintain accuracy near \e x = 0.  In addition, the odd parity of the
00189      * function is enforced.
00190      **********************************************************************/
00191     static inline real atanh(real x) throw() {
00192       real y = std::abs(x);     // Enforce odd parity
00193       y = log1p(2 * y/(1 - y))/2;
00194       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00195     }
00196 #else
00197     static inline double atanh(double x) throw() { return ::atanh(x); }
00198     static inline float atanh(float x) throw() { return ::atanhf(x); }
00199     static inline long double atanh(long double x) throw()
00200     { return ::atanhl(x); }
00201 #endif
00202 
00203 #if defined(DOXYGEN) || defined(_MSC_VER)
00204     /**
00205      * Return the real cube root of \e x.
00206      **********************************************************************/
00207     static inline real cbrt(real x) throw() {
00208       real y = std::pow(std::abs(x), 1/real(3)); // Return the real cube root
00209       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00210     }
00211 #else
00212     static inline double cbrt(double x) throw() { return ::cbrt(x); }
00213     static inline float cbrt(float x) throw() { return ::cbrtf(x); }
00214     static inline long double cbrt(long double x) throw() { return ::cbrtl(x); }
00215 #endif
00216 
00217 #if defined(DOXYGEN)
00218     /**
00219      * Return true if number is finite, false if NaN or infinite.
00220      **********************************************************************/
00221     static inline bool isfinite(real x) throw() {
00222       return std::abs(x) < std::numeric_limits<real>::max();
00223     }
00224 #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
00225     static inline real isfinite(real x) throw() { return _finite(x); }
00226 #else
00227     static inline real isfinite(real x) throw() { return std::isfinite(x); }
00228 #endif
00229   };

00231   /**
00232    * \brief %Constants needed by %GeographicLib
00233    *
00234    * Define constants specifying the WGS84 ellipsoid, the UTM and UPS
00235    * projections, and various unit conversions.
00236    **********************************************************************/
00237   class Constants {
00238   private:
00239     typedef Math::real real;
00240     Constants();                // Disable constructor
00241 
00242   public:
00243     /**
00244      * pi
00245      **********************************************************************/
00246     static inline Math::real pi() throw()
00247     // good for about 123-bit accuracy
00248     { return real(3.141592653589793238462643383279502884L); }
00249     /**
00250      * Factor to convert from degrees to radians
00251      **********************************************************************/
00252     static inline Math::real degree() throw() { return pi() / 180; }
00253     /**
00254      * Factor to convert from minutes to radians
00255      **********************************************************************/
00256     static inline Math::real arcminute() throw() { return degree() / 60; }
00257     /**
00258      * Factor to convert from seconds to radians
00259      **********************************************************************/
00260     static inline Math::real arcsecond() throw() { return arcminute() / 60; }
00261 
00262     /** \name Ellipsoid parameters
00263      **********************************************************************/
00264     ///@{
00265     /**
00266      * Major radius of WGS84 ellipsoid
00267      **********************************************************************/
00268     static inline Math::real WGS84_a() throw() { return 6378137 * meter(); }
00269     /**
00270      * Reciprocal flattening of WGS84 ellipsoid
00271      **********************************************************************/
00272     static inline Math::real WGS84_r() throw() { return real(298.257223563L); }
00273     /**
00274      * Central scale factor for UTM
00275      **********************************************************************/
00276     static inline Math::real UTM_k0() throw() {return real(0.9996L); }
00277     /**
00278      * Central scale factor for UPS
00279      **********************************************************************/
00280     static inline Math::real UPS_k0() throw() { return real(0.994L); }
00281     ///@}
00282 
00283     /** \name SI units
00284      **********************************************************************/
00285     ///@{
00286     /**
00287      * Factor to convert from meters to meters (i.e., 1, but this lets the
00288      * internal system of units be changed if necessary).
00289      **********************************************************************/
00290     static inline Math::real meter() throw() { return real(1); }
00291     /**
00292      * Factor to convert from kilometers to meters.
00293      **********************************************************************/
00294     static inline Math::real kilometer() throw() { return 1000 * meter(); }
00295     ///@}
00296 
00297     /**
00298      * Factor to convert from nautical miles (approximately 1 arc minute) to
00299      * meters.
00300      **********************************************************************/
00301     static inline Math::real nauticalmile() throw() { return 1852 * meter(); }
00302 
00303     /** \name Anachronistic British units
00304      **********************************************************************/
00305     ///@{
00306     /**
00307      * Factor to convert from international feet to meters.
00308      **********************************************************************/
00309     static inline Math::real foot() throw()
00310     { return real(0.0254L) * 12 * meter(); }
00311     /**
00312      * Factor to convert from yards to meters.
00313      **********************************************************************/
00314     static inline Math::real yard() throw() { return 3 * foot(); }
00315     /**
00316      * Factor to convert from fathoms to meters.
00317      **********************************************************************/
00318     static inline Math::real fathom() throw() { return 2 * yard(); }
00319     /**
00320      * Factor to convert from chains to meters.
00321      **********************************************************************/
00322     static inline Math::real chain() throw() { return 22 * yard(); }
00323     /**
00324      * Factor to convert from furlongs to meters.
00325      **********************************************************************/
00326     static inline Math::real furlong() throw() { return 10 * chain(); }
00327     /**
00328      * Factor to convert from statute miles to meters.
00329      **********************************************************************/
00330     static inline Math::real mile() throw() { return 8 * furlong(); }
00331     ///@}
00332 
00333     /** \name Anachronistic US units
00334      **********************************************************************/
00335     ///@{
00336     /**
00337      * Factor to convert from US survery feet to meters.
00338      **********************************************************************/
00339     static inline Math::real surveyfoot() throw()
00340     { return real(1200) / real(3937) * meter(); }
00341     ///@}
00342   };

00344   /**
00345    * \brief %Exception handling for %GeographicLib
00346    *
00347    * A class to handle exceptions.  It's derived off std::runtime_error so it
00348    * can be caught by the usual catch clauses.
00349    **********************************************************************/
00350   class GeographicErr : public std::runtime_error {
00351   public:
00352 
00353     /**
00354      * Constructor takes a string message, \e msg, which is accessible in the
00355      * catch clause, via what().
00356      **********************************************************************/
00357     GeographicErr(const std::string& msg) : std::runtime_error(msg) {}
00358   };
